poem:
"Swapping Threads, Weaving Change"

In discarded seams and worn-out dreams,
Mancilla and Macias sowed seeds of change.
'Tween commerce's greed and nature's need, 
They saw a balance fit to arrange.
Fast fashion's waste and thrifting's haste, 
In hands of two became reborn—
As the Los Angeles twine spun tales of time,
In newly swapped, yet old, clothes worn.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Fast fashion is wasteful, and thrifting is flawed. The solution: swap! Jannine Mancilla, 32, and Nicole Macias, 34, bonded over a shared love of DIY fashion and hand-me-downs, and frustrations with an environmentally-destructive industry and a throwaway culture that creates huge amounts of waste. So they came up with a radical idea: asking people to offer up their old clothes – for free. Their Los Angeles clothing swaps have grown from humble origins to “overwhelmingly”". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
